review.title: The Most Persistent Soft-Clique in a Set of Sampled Graphs
review.abstract: When searching for characteristic subpatterns in potentially noisy graph data, it appears self-evident that having multiple observations would be better than having just one. However, it turns out that the inconsistencies introduced when different graph instances have different edge sets pose a serious challenge. In this work we address this challenge for the problem of finding maximum weighted cliques.

metadata.title: The Most Persistent Soft-Clique in a Set of Sampled Graphs

sections.text: We present the concept of the most stubborn soft clique, which is a subset of vertices that 1) is almost completely or at least tightly connected to each other, 2) occurs in all or almost all diagram examples, and 3) has the maximum weight. We present a measure of cliqueness that essentially counts the number of missing edges to make a subset of vertices a clique. With this measurement, we show that the problem of finding the most stubborn soft clique problem can be defined either as: a) a maximum-minute-long two-person optimization problem, or b) a minute-long soft margin optimization problem. Both formulations result in the use of a partial positioning method to solve the optimization problems. By experimenting with synthetic data and real data from social networks, we show that the proposed method is capable of finding soft cliquettes in unreliable, even if distorted by noise.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion and Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced the concept of persistent soft cliques, i.e. subgraphs that are almost completely or at least tightly connected and persist through all or most instances of the graph. This concept is particularly useful for characterizing key patterns more securely when multiple instances of a graph are available for analysis. We presented a soft clique measure that counts and penalizes the number of missing edges to make the selected subgraphs a clique, to deal with inconsistent patterns inherent in noisy graph instances. If this measure is used in an optimization frame to find a maximum weighted clique, we end up with a two-person game or a limp formulation. We demonstrated with a Lagrange method that the two formulations lead to the same solution.Our experiments with randomly generated inconsistent patterns in multiple settings of the original graph confirmed that a collection of, even loud snapshots, of a particular time leads to a specific graph.

metadata.abstractText: When searching for characteristic subpatterns in potentially noisy graph data, it appears self-evident that having multiple observations would be better than having just one. However, it turns out that the inconsistencies introduced when different graph instances have different edge sets pose a serious challenge. In this work we address this challenge for the problem of finding maximum weighted cliques. We introduce the concept of most persistent soft-clique. This is subset of vertices, that 1) is almost fully or at least densely connected, 2) occurs in all or almost all graph instances, and 3) has the maximum weight. We present a measure of clique-ness, that essentially counts the number of edge missing to make a subset of vertices into a clique. With this measure, we show that the problem of finding the most persistent soft-clique problem can be cast either as: a) a max-min two person game optimization problem, or b) a min-min soft margin optimization problem. Both formulations lead to the same solution when using a partial Lagrangian method to solve the optimization problems. By experiments on synthetic data and on real social network data we show that the proposed method is able to reliably find soft cliques in graph data, even if that is distorted by random noise or unreliable observations.
